qas.question: What were both Serbian and Croation standards based on?
Which language officially served the Kingdom of Yugoslavia?
What ethnic names does Serbo-Croatian associate with?

answers.text: Serbian, Croatian, Bosnian, and sometimes Montenegrin and Bunjevac

qas.question: In what year was a Yugoslav state standardized?
What agreement helped standardize Eastern Herzegovinian?

plausible_answers.text: the same Shtokavian subdialect, Eastern Herzegovinian

qas.question: What were Yugoaslav and Bosnian standards based on?
In the mid 19th century what was the official language of Yugoslavia?

plausible_answers.text: social conceptions of the language separated on ethnic and political lines

qas.question: How did the break-up of Croatia affect the language?

context: Serbo-Croatian was standardized <b3_0>in the mid-19th-century<b3_0/> <b4_0>Vienna Literary Agreement<b4_0/> by Croatian and Serbian writers and philologists, decades before a Yugoslav state was established. From the very beginning, there were slightly different literary Serbian and Croatian standards, although both were based on <b5_0>the same <a0_0>Shtokavian subdialect, Eastern Herzegovinian<b5_0/><a0_0/>. In the 20th century, <a1_0><b6_0>Serbo-Croatian<b6_0/><a1_0/> served as the official language of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia (when it was called "Serbo-Croato-Slovenian"), and later as one of the official languages of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. The breakup of Yugoslavia affected language attitudes, so that <b7_0>social conceptions of the language separated on ethnic and political lines<b7_0/>. Since the breakup of Yugoslavia, Bosnian has likewise been established as an official standard in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and there is an ongoing movement to codify a separate Montenegrin standard. Serbo-Croatian thus generally goes by the ethnic names <a2_0>Serbian, Croatian, Bosnian, and sometimes Montenegrin and Bunjevac<a2_0/>.
